source.title: Single Cell Barcoding and Reverse Transcription

source.description: Prepare cells for isolation and encapsulation in gel bead emulsions (GEMs). If your experiment involves a piggyBac transposase with PB-SRT-Puro transposons, cells that have survived sleection should be dissociated and resuspended in solution. If you are using piggyBac with PB-SRT-tdTomato, we recommend using FACS to isolate tdTomato-positive cells, running cells transfected with PB-SRT-tdTomato alone as a gating control.

source.title: Single Cell Barcoding and Reverse Transcription

source.description:
Follow
10x's instructions
for GEM Generation & Barcoding, with this modification:
    Proceed with Steps 1.2–1.5 as instructed: loading the Single Cell 3' chip, running the controller, transferring GEMs, and reverse transcription.
    Incubate the RT reaction under standard conditions.
    Set lid temperature to
    Hold at

source.title: Single Cell Barcoding and Reverse Transcription

source.description: Step 2.1: clean the GEM-RT mixture using the Recovery Agent and DynaBeads MyOne Silane per 10x's instructions. At the final elution stage, add 36.5 µl Elution Solution I to the tube, mix by pipetting, and incubate at room temperature for 1 minute. Place the tube in a 10x Magnetic Separator in the Low position until the solution turns clear. Transfer 36 µl of the eluted sample to a new tube.

source.title: Single Cell Barcoding and Reverse Transcription

source.description: Divide the eluate into two 18-µl aliquots. These can be stored at –20ºC until needed. One aliquot will be used for scRNA-seq library preparation, while the other will be used to generate scCC libraries.

source.title: Single Cell RNA-seq Library Preparation and Sequencing

source.description: To continue preparing scRNA-seq libraries, we need to add the template switch oligonucleotide to first strand synthesis products from the RT reaction. Take one of the 18 µl aliquots and thaw on ice.

source.title: Single Cell RNA-seq Library Preparation and Sequencing

source.description:
Prepare the following 1X master mix:
  • 20 µl Maxima 5X RT buffer
  • 20 µl 20% w/v Ficoll PM-400
  • 10 µl 10 mM dNTPs
  • 2.5 µl RNaseOUT
  • 2.5 µl 100 µM 10x_TSO

source.title: Single Cell RNA-seq Library Preparation and Sequencing

source.description: To the mix, add 18 µl of first strand RT product and 22 µl H2O. Add 5 µl Maxima H– RTase to the reaction, flick to the mix, and centrifuge briefly.

source.title: Single Cell RNA-seq Library Preparation and Sequencing

source.description: Incubate:

source.title: Single Cell RNA-seq Library Preparation and Sequencing

source.description: Clean up following 10x's post GEM-RT Cleanup protocol, starting with the addition of DynaBeads MyOne Silane (Step 2.1, part D). Clean samples per manufacturer's instructions.

source.title: Single Cell RNA-seq Library Preparation and Sequencing

source.description: Complete cDNA amplification and library construction according to the 10x's instructions (Steps 2.2–3.7). For each sample, record which index sample index was used for the final PCR. Quantiate each library by running a 1:10 dilution on an Agilent TapeStation High Sensitivity D1000 ScreenTape.

source.title: Single Cell RNA-seq Library Preparation and Sequencing

source.description: Finished scRNA-seq libraries can be pooled and sequenced on Illumina MiSeq, NextSeq, HiSeq, and NovaSeq platforms.

source.title: Amplification of Self-Reporting Transcripts

source.description: To prepare single cell calling cards libraries, we start by amplifying self-reporting transcripts from the other aliquot of first-strand synthesis product. As before, thaw the remaining 18 µl aliquot on ice.

source.title: Amplification of Self-Reporting Transcripts

source.description:
Prepare the following PCR mix in PCR tube:
  • 25 µl of 2X Kapa HiFi Hotstart Readymix
  • 18 µl of first-strand synthesis product
  • 6 µl of ddH2O
  • 1 µl of PCR primer cocktail
Keep on ice until ready for PCR.

source.title: Amplification of Self-Reporting Transcripts

source.description:
Prepare a PCR primer cocktail in a PCR tube:
  • 5 µl of 100 µM Bio_Illumina_Seq1_scCC_10X_3xPT primer
  • 5 µl of 100 µM Bio_Long_PB_LTR_3xPT primer
  • 10 µl of Low TE Buffer
Mix by vortexing and spin down briefly. This cocktail can be stored at –20ºC.

source.title: Amplification of Self-Reporting Transcripts

source.description:
Perform PCR using the following thermocycling parameters:
  • 98ºC for 3 minutes
  • 20 cycles of:
  • 98ºC for 20 seconds
  • 67ºC for 30 seconds
  • 72ºC for 5 minutes
  • 72ºC for 10 minutes
  • 4ºC forever.
The number of cycles may need to be adjusted depending on the cell type and number of cells represented in the library. If uncertain, you can use 9 µl of first-strand synthesis product as template, reserving the other 9 µl for another round of PCR with more cycles as needed.

source.title: Purification of PCR Products

source.description: Vortex AMPure XP beads to resuspend them. Beads should be brought to room temperature for at least 30 minutes prior to use.

source.title: Purification of PCR Products

source.description: Add 30 µl beads to the 50 µl PCR mixture (0.6x ratio). Mix by pipetting 10 times until evenly dispersed.

source.title: Purification of PCR Products

source.description: Incubate at room temperature for

source.title: Purification of PCR Products

source.description:
Place on a magnetic rack for
Aspirate supernatant and discard.

source.title: Purification of PCR Products

source.description: While the tube is still on the rack, add 200 µl of 70% ethanol and incubate ≥ 30 seconds. Aspirate supernatant and discard.

source.title: Purification of PCR Products

source.description: Repeat Step #20

source.title: Purification of PCR Products

source.description: Air dry the pellet at room temperature for

source.title: Purification of PCR Products

source.description: Remove the tube from the magnetic rack. Add 40 µl QIAGEN Elution Buffer to elute PCR products. Mix by pipetting until evenly dispersed. Incubate off the rack for

source.title: Purification of PCR Products

source.description:
Place on magnetic rack for
or until supernatant is clear. Transfer supernatant to new 1.7 ml tube.

source.title: Purification of PCR Products

source.description:
Take 1 µl of the eluate and dilute in 9 µl of ddH2O to make a 1:10 dilution. Quantitate on TapeStation using a High Sensitivity D5000 ScreenTape. Measure the molar concentration of the sample, taking everything from 250 bp to 7000 bp. Ideally, the diluted sample will be at least 750 pM, corresponding to 7.5 nM for the original eluate. If you kept half of the template aside, you can increase the number of PCR extension cycles until you get to a minimum of 7.5 nM of product.
This is what a representative TapeStation trace looks like. The library should be smooth and unimodal.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Circularization

source.description: Thaw an aliquot of CB – Circularization Buffer 10X on ice.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Exonuclease and Setup

source.description: Add 9 µl of PS1 – Exonuclease directly to the overnight circularization mixture. Flick to mix, spin down, and incubate as following:

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Shearing and Capture

source.description: Transfer the entire sample (now approximately 320 µl) to a Covaris T6 tube. Add ddH2O as necessary to fill to the top, then cap the tube. Check to make sure there are no air bubbles.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Circularization

source.description:
Add the following components to a new 1.7 ml tube in this order:
  1. 300 fmol self-reporting transcripts from Step 25
  2. ddH2O up to a total of 268 µl
  3. 30 µl CB
  4. 2 µl Circularization Ligase
To calculate what volume of eluate corresponds to 300 fmol, divide 300 by the molar concentration (in nM) of the eluate. For example, if the concentration is 10 nM, 300 fmol/10 nM = 30 µl, and consequently you would need 238 µl ddH2O. If you have less than 300 fmol total, you may proceed but might need to make adjustments at the final PCR step. If you do not have a way to quantitate the molarity of your solution, we have observed that 300 fmol of self-reporting transcripts is (very) approximately 200 ng.
Mix by flicking the tube and spin down briefly. Incubate at
overnight (12-16 hours).

source.body: We strongly encourage you to calculate the volume of SRT solution based on molarity, not by mass. The circularization reaction is sensitive to starting concentration. If overloaded, it can lead to excess intermolecular ligations and, subsequently, increased noise with respect to the assignment of insertions to cell types.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Exonuclease and Setup

source.description:
While the exonuclease digestion proceeds, prepare for the rest of the library preparation. Fill a large ice bucket with ice. Thaw, on ice, aliquots of:
  • STL – Stop Ligation Buffer
  • ERP3 – End Repair Mix
  • ATL2 – A-tailing Mix
  • LIG2 – Ligation Mix
  • EPM – Enhanced PCR Mix
  • Also thaw the following oligonucleotides:
  • scCC_P5_adapter (100 µM)
  • scCC_P7_adapter (100 µM)
  • scCC_P5_primer (25 µM)
  • scCC_P7_primer (25 µM)
Also thaw the following oligonucleotides:
  • scCC_P5_adapter (100 µM)
  • scCC_P7_adapter (100 µM)
  • scCC_P5_primer (25 µM)
  • scCC_P7_primer (25 µM)
Finally, thaw NEBuffer 2

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Exonuclease and Setup

source.description:
While the exonuclease incubates, anneal the scCC adapters. Prepare the following mixture in a PCR tube, using a different indexed scCC_P7_adapter for each sample:
  • 4.5 µl scCC_P5_adapter
  • 4.5 µl scCC_P7_adapter
  • 1 µl NEBuffer 2

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Exonuclease and Setup

source.description: The exonuclease digestion should be complete by now. Add 12 µl STL – Stop Ligation Buffer. Flix to mix and centrifuge gently.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Exonuclease and Setup

source.description: Prepare the streptavidin-coated magnetic beads. These instructions are for 1 sample; up to 5 can be prepared in a single 1.7 ml tube. Resuspend Dynabeads M-280 by vortexing briefly.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Exonuclease and Setup

source.description: Remove from rack and add 300 µl BBB. Beads can be stored at room temperature until needed.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Exonuclease and Setup

source.description: Transfer 20 µl of beads to a clean 1.7 ml tube.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Exonuclease and Setup

source.description: Place on a magnetic rack for 1 minute. Once clear, aspirate and discard supernatant.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Exonuclease and Setup

source.description: Add 40 µl BBB – Bead Bind Buffer. Incubate for 1 minute, then aspirate and discard supernatant.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Exonuclease and Setup

source.description: Repeat Step #35.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Exonuclease and Setup

source.description:
Anneal scCC adapters in a thermocycler using the following settings:
  • 95ºC for 5 minutes
  • 70ºC for 15 minutes
  • Ramp down to 25ºC as slowly as possible
  • 25ºC for 5 minutes
  • 4ºC forever
scCC adapters can be kept on ice until needed.

source.body: Adapters should be prepared fresh. NEBuffer 2 contains magnesium salts which can promote DNase activity, leading to degradation of adapters.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Shearing and Capture

source.description:
Shear DNA on a Covaris ultrasonicator. Here are recommended settings for various models (we have tested this protocol on the E220):
ABCD
1ModelS2S220E220
2Peak Power IntensityN/A240200
3Intensity8N/AN/A
4Duty Cycle/Factor20%20%20%
5Cycles Per Burst200200200
6Time404040
7Temperature666

ABCD
1ModelS2S220E220
2Peak Power IntensityN/A240200
3Intensity8N/AN/A
4Duty Cycle/Factor20%20%20%
5Cycles Per Burst200200200
6Time404040
7Temperature666

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Shearing and Capture

source.description: Transfer the sample to a new 1.7 ml tube. Add 300 µl of bead solution to the sheared DNA.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Shearing and Capture

source.description:
Incubate
If incubating on a thermoshaker, shake at 1000 RPM. Otherwise, flick to mix every 2 minutes.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Shearing and Capture

source.description: Centrifuge briefly (5-10 seconds), then place on a magnetic rack for 1 minute. Discard the supernatant.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Shearing and Capture

source.description:
Wash 4 times with BWB – Bead Wash Buffer:
  • Add 200 µl BWB
  • Remove from rack, flick to mix, and spin down briefly (1-2 seconds)
  • Place on rack for 30 seconds
  • Discard supernatant
Repeat for a total for 4 washes

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Shearing and Capture

source.description:
Wash 2 times with RSB – Resuspension Buffer:
  • Add 200 µl RSB
  • Remove from rack, flick to mix, and spin down briefly
  • Place on rack for 30 seconds
  • Discard supernatant
For the second wash, do not discard supernatant until ready to add the master mix in the next step.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – End Repair, A-Tailing, and Adapter Ligation

source.description:
Prepare master mixes for End Repair and A-Tailing as follows.
1X End Repair Master Mix:
  • 40 µl ERP3 – End Repair Mix
  • 60 µl ddH2O
  • 1X A-Tailing Master Mix:
  • 12.5 µl ATL2 – A-Tailing Mix
  • 17.5 µl ddH2O
1X A-Tailing Master Mix:
  • 12.5 µl ATL2 – A-Tailing Mix
  • 17.5 µl ddH2O

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – End Repair, A-Tailing, and Adapter Ligation

source.description: Discard all supernatant from the DNA sample. Centrifuge briefly, then place on a magnetic rack.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – End Repair, A-Tailing, and Adapter Ligation

source.description: Use a 10 µl pipette to aspirate any residual supernatant.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – End Repair, A-Tailing, and Adapter Ligation

source.description: Add 100 µl End Repair reaction mix, remove from the rack, flick to mix, and centrifuge briefly (do not allow beads to pellet).

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – End Repair, A-Tailing, and Adapter Ligation

source.description:
Incubate
If incubating on a thermoshaker, shake at 1000 RPM, to prevent beads from settling.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – End Repair, A-Tailing, and Adapter Ligation

source.description: Centrifuge briefly (5-10 seconds), then place on a magnetic rack for 1 minute. Discard the supernatant.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – End Repair, A-Tailing, and Adapter Ligation

source.description:
Wash 4 times with BWB – Bead Wash Buffer:
  • Add 200 µl BWB
  • Remove from rack, flick to mix, and spin down briefly (1-2 seconds)
  • Place on rack for 30 seconds
  • Discard supernatant
Repeat for a total for 4 washes

For the second wash, do not discard supernatant until ready to add the master mix in the next step.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – End Repair, A-Tailing, and Adapter Ligation

source.description: Discard all supernatant from the DNA sample. Centrifuge briefly, then place on a magnetic rack. Use a 10 µl pipette to aspirate any residual supernatant.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – End Repair, A-Tailing, and Adapter Ligation

source.description: Add 30 µl A-Tailing reaction mix, remove from the rack, flick to mix, and centrifuge briefly (do not allow beads to pellet).

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – End Repair, A-Tailing, and Adapter Ligation

source.description:
Incubate
If incubating on a thermoshaker, shake at 1000 RPM, to prevent beads from settling.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – End Repair, A-Tailing, and Adapter Ligation

source.description:
Add the following components in order to the A-tailing mix:
  • (30 µl A-tailing reaction)
  • 2.5 µl LIG2 – Ligation Mix
  • 4 µl ddH2O
  • 1 µl annealed scCC adapter
Flick to mix and centrifuge briefly (do not allow beads to pellet).

source.description: Centrifuge briefly (5-10 seconds), then place on a magnetic rack for 1 minute. Discard the supernatant.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – End Repair, A-Tailing, and Adapter Ligation

source.description:
Wash 4 times with BWB – Bead Wash Buffer:
  • Add 200 µl BWB
  • Remove from rack, flick to mix, and spin down briefly (1-2 seconds)
  • Place on rack for 30 seconds

Repeat for a total for 4 washes

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – End Repair, A-Tailing, and Adapter Ligation

For the second wash, do not discard supernatant until ready to add the master mix in the next step.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Final PCR and Purification

source.description:
Prepare a 1X PCR master mix in a new 1.7 ml tube:
  • 20 µl EPM – Enhanced PCR Mix
  • 28 µl ddH2O
  • 1 µl scCC_P5_primer (25 µM)
  • 1 µl scCC_P7_primer (25 µM)

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Final PCR and Purification

source.description: Discard all supernatant from the DNA sample. Centrifuge briefly, then place on a magnetic rack. Use a 10 µl pipette to aspirate any residual supernatant.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Final PCR and Purification

source.description: Add 50 µl PCR reaction mix to the sample and pipette to mix. Transfer to PCR tubes.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Final PCR and Purification

source.description:
Incubate in a thermocycler with the following settings:
  • 98ºC for 30 seconds
  • 15 cycles of:
  • 98ºC for 10 seconds
  • 60ºC for 30 seconds
  • 72ºC for 2 minutes
  • 72ºC for 5 minutes
  • 4ºC forever.

source.body: If you started with less than 300 fmol of self-reporting transcripts, you can increase the number of extension cycles here. More cycles will increase the risk of artifacts, however, so we recommend increasing by the minimum necessary to obtain reasonable sequencing libraries. The most we have pushed this PCR is to 17 extension cycles.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Final PCR and Purification

source.description: Vortex AMPure XP beads to resuspend them. Beads should be brought to room temperature for at least 30 minutes prior to use.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Final PCR and Purification

source.description: Place PCR tubes on a magnetic rack for 1 minute. Transfer 50 µl of supernatant to new tubes.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Final PCR and Purification

source.description: Add 35 µl beads to the 50 µl PCR mixture (0.7x ratio). Flick to mix and centrifuge briefly.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Final PCR and Purification

source.description: Incubate at room temperature for

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Final PCR and Purification

source.description:
Make a 1:10 dilution of the eluate and quantitate on TapeStation using a High Sensitivity D1000 ScreenTape. Measure the molar concentration of the sample, taking everything from 200 bp to 1300 bp.
This is what a representative TapeStation trace looks like. The library should be smooth and unimodal, peaking between 500-700 bp. Occasionally, you may see a primer-dimer peak. However, as scCC libraries are sequenced from the middle and not the ends, the primer-dimer product will not sequence on the Illumina flow cell.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Sequencing

source.description:
Single cell calling cards libraries use a mix of standard and custom primers for sequencing and rely on dual-indexing for proper demutiplexing. We have sequenced scCC libraries on Illumina NextSeq 500 machines, using v2 Reagent Cartridges. These libraries use the standard Illumina primers BP10 and BP14 for read 1 and index 2, respectively. Read 1 sequences the cell barcode and unique molecular index (UMI), while index 2 reads into the terminal repeat of the piggyBac transposon, confirming that molecules successfully circularized.
In addition, we use the custom sequencing primers scCC_PB_CustomRead2 and scCC_CustomIndex1 for read 2 and index 1, respectively. Read 2 anneals at the end of the transposon and sequences into the genome. The first six base pairs typically begin "GGTTAA", which are the terminal two base pairs of the piggyBac repeat followed by the insertion site tetramer. The remainder of the read is genomic DNA sequence. Index 1 sequences the sample-specific sequence on the scCC adapter and is used to demultiplex libraries.

source.body: Due to the low complexity nature of calling card libraries, we recommed adding PhiX at a final concentration of 50%.

source.title: Single Cell Calling Cards – Sequencing

source.description:
While index 1 should be sufficient to demultiplex libraries, we have observed a biphasic response when sequencing scCC libraries at low and high concentrations. At low library concentrations, (e.g., 1-2%) the index 1 read generates high-quality reads and can demultiplex libraries; however at higher concentrations (i.e., 50%) the index 1 read can fail, yielding all N's. If this happens, libraries can be demultiplexed by the index 2 read alone: scCC reads that have successfully circularized will have "GCGTCAAT" as the index 2 sequence.
After this, scCC reads can be assigned to specific samples using the cell barcodes obtained from the corresponding scRNA-seq libraries. Different libraries may, by chance, have cells that share the same cell barcode. Typically, these represent a very small fraction of cells (< 1% per library) and we discard these reads and cells from downstream calling cards and scRNA-seq analyses, respectively.

materials.name: Maxima H Minus Reverse Transcriptase (200 U/uL)
Chromium Single Cell 3′ Library & Gel Bead Kit v2
Chromium Single Cell A Chip Kit
Nextera Mate Pair Library Prep Kit
1.7 ml Axygen Maxymum Recovery Microcentrifuge Tubes
Covaris T6 (6 x 32 mm) glass tubes
Covaris Snap-Cap - Teflon Silicone Septa 8 mm

description: This protocol describes how to create calling card libraries from single cell RNA. We assume you have successfully transformed cells with piggyBac self-reporting transposons and either undirected piggyBac transposase or your favorite transcription factor (YFTF) fused to piggyBac. We also assume you have optimized the dissociation protocol for your specific cells or tissues and can generate single cell suspensions.
